items.title: How the internet reacted to the fifth Ashes Test
items.description: The internet went wild as Australia dominated with the bat, led by Travis Head and Steve Smith, and England crumbled in the dying embers of the Ashes.

items.title: Greenlanders who once laughed at Trump's annexation talk now feel 'scared'
items.description: The United States has a long history of wanting to acquire Greenland, but people living on the island say Donald Trump's latest comments about annexation feel different.

items.title: Antisemitism inquiry welcome, but some say it was called too late
items.description: Community groups that lobbied for a national inquiry into antisemitism have mostly welcomed the prime minister's announcement of a royal commission.

items.title: FBI accused of barring local authorities from Minnesota ICE shooting investigation
items.description: The shooting claimed the life of 37-year-old mother-of-three Renee Nicole Good, and has prompted protests and heated political debate.

items.title: Heatwave, fire threat peaking as temperatures nudge record-highs
items.description: Southern states continue to sweat through one of the most intense heatwaves on record, and for many regions, including Melbourne and Sydney, the hottest weather is still to come.

items.title: As she turns 44, Princess Catherine is quietly reshaping royal life
items.description: Catherine turns 44 today as she resets royal life with fewer public appearances, tighter boundaries and a strong emphasis on family life — a choice shaped by loss, illness and the pressure of being next in line.

items.title: Antarctic iceberg and Thwaites Glacier show instability

featured_image.name: The world's oldest and largest iceberg will soon be no more - NPR

items.description:
Satellite observations and seismic monitoring have revealed alarming developments at two of Antarctica's most closely watched ice formations, raising fresh concerns about the stability of the continent's ice sheet and its potential contribution to sea level rise.

NASA's Terra satellite captured images on December 26, 2025, showing iceberg A-23A covered in extensive pools of blue meltwater, indicating the massive berg could disintegrate within days or weeks[1]. Separately, a study published in Geophysical Research Letters detected more than 360 glacial earthquakes near Antarctica's Thwaites Glacier between 2010 and 2023, with 245 concentrated at the marine end of the glacier known as the "Doomsday Glacier"[2][3][4].

items.title: French, Greek farmers blockade cities ahead of EU-Mercosur vote

featured_image.name: French farmers force their way through Paris with tractors to protest free trade deal

items.description:
Farmers in France and Greece launched major tractor protests on Thursday, blocking highways and storming central Paris to oppose the European Union's looming free trade agreement with South American nations, escalating a months-long battle over agricultural policy just ahead of a critical vote on Friday[1][2][3].

Around 100 tractors forced their way into the French capital, bypassing police barriers to reach landmarks including the Eiffel Tower and the Arc de Triomphe[1][4]. In Greece, farmers initiated a 48-hour blockade of major highways and toll stations, shutting down key routes including the main highway connecting Athens to Thessaloniki[3][5].

items.title: Shell shares drop on weak trading, chemicals losses

featured_image.name: Shell posts weaker-than-expected full-year profit on lower ...

items.description:
Shell shares dropped as much as 2.6% Thursday after the energy giant warned of weaker fourth-quarter trading results and losses in its chemicals division, raising doubts about whether the company can maintain its $3.5 billion quarterly share buyback program[1][2][3][4].

The London-based company said trading results for the fourth quarter of 2025 would be "significantly lower" than the previous three months, with its chemicals and products segment expected to swing to an adjusted loss[1][5][3][6]. Oil trading represents a major portion of Shell's trading operations, alongside refined products such as diesel and gasoline[1][3][7].

items.title: Arctic sees surge in unprecedented extreme weather events

featured_image.name: Scientists issue warning about dangerous phenomenon escalating ...

items.description:
The Arctic recorded its hottest year since measurements began 125 years ago, while a new study reveals the region has entered an unprecedented era of extreme weather events that threaten ecosystems and communities across the polar north.

Temperatures from October 2024 through September 2025 were the warmest in the Arctic since 1900, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's annual Arctic Report Card released in December[1][2][3]. The past decade represents the 10 warmest years on record for the region[1][2][3]. In March 2025, Arctic winter sea ice reached its lowest annual maximum extent in the 47-year satellite record[1][4][5].

Research published this week in the journal Science Advances documents a sharp increase in extreme weather events across the Arctic over the past 30 years[6][7][8]. The study, led by the Finnish Meteorological Institute with an international team including the University of Sheffield, found that approximately one-third of the Arctic land area has recently begun experiencing extreme weather events that had not occurred there previously[6][7][8].

items.title: Scientists map Milky Way neutrino flow to Earth

featured_image.name: Antarctic Experiment Maps the Milky Way Galaxy's High-Energy ...

items.description:
Astrophysicists have produced the first comprehensive model of neutrino emissions from all stars in the Milky Way, providing researchers with a roadmap to detect these elusive particles and unlock new insights into stellar physics.

The study, published January 7 in Physical Review D, estimates how many neutrinos reach Earth from the galaxy's stars and pinpoints their origins[1][2][3][4]. Every second, a trillion neutrinos pass through the human body without interaction, earning them the nickname "ghost particles"[1][3][4].

"For the first time, we have a concrete estimate of how many of these particles reach Earth, where in the galaxy they come from, and how their energy is distributed," said lead author Pablo Martínez-Miravé, a postdoc at the University of Copenhagen's Niels Bohr Institute[1][3][4].

items.title: Swedish team makes hydrogen without platinum using conductive plastic

featured_image.name: Solar hydrogen can now be produced efficiently, no platinum ...

items.description:
Researchers at Chalmers University of Technology in Sweden have developed a method to produce hydrogen gas using sunlight and water without platinum, potentially removing one of the most significant cost barriers in green hydrogen production. The breakthrough, published this week in the journal Advanced Materials, replaces the scarce and expensive metal with nanoparticles made from electrically conductive plastic[1][2][3][4].

The innovation addresses a critical challenge in the transition to renewable energy. While hydrogen produces only water as a byproduct when used, its production has long relied on platinum as a co-catalyst—a metal with limited global reserves concentrated primarily in South Africa and Russia, according to the research team[2][3]. The extraction process poses environmental and health risks, and platinum's scarcity has hampered efforts to scale green hydrogen production[2][3].

items.title: China to approve Nvidia H200 chip imports this quarter

featured_image.name: China to Approve Nvidia H200 Buying as Soon as This Quarter

items.description:
China is preparing to authorize imports of Nvidia's H200 artificial intelligence chips as soon as this quarter, according to people familiar with the matter, marking a significant reopening of a market that has been largely cut off from the world's leading AI chip maker for more than two years[1][2][3].

Chinese officials are readying approval for domestic companies to purchase the chips for select commercial applications, the people said[1][2][4]. However, the military, sensitive government agencies, critical infrastructure operators, and state-owned enterprises will remain barred from using the H200 due to security concerns[1][2][4][5]—restrictions similar to those Beijing has previously imposed on products from Apple and Micron Technology[4][3].

Tech giants Alibaba and ByteDance have privately indicated interest in ordering more than 200,000 H200 units each once approval is granted, according to a person familiar with the matter[4][3][6]. The companies, along with Chinese AI startups including DeepSeek, are racing to upgrade their models to compete with OpenAI and other U.S. rivals[4][7][8].

items.title: China restricts rare earth exports to Japan despite civilian-use pledges

featured_image.name: China curbs rare earth exports to Japanese companies after ...

items.description:
China has begun restricting rare earth exports to Japanese companies despite official assurances that civilian users would remain unaffected, escalating a dispute triggered by Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's comments on Taiwan.

On Thursday, Chinese commerce ministry spokesperson He Yadong said the export ban on dual-use items to Japan would only impact military firms and that "civilian users will not be affected"[1][2][3]. However, The Wall Street Journal reported that China has started restricting exports of heavy rare earths and magnets broadly across Japanese industries since Tuesday, contradicting Beijing's official stance[4][5].

Japan lodged a formal protest Thursday when Vice Foreign Minister Takehiro Funakoshi met with Chinese Ambassador Wu Jianghao in Tokyo, demanding China withdraw the measures[6][7][8]. Wu rejected the protest, according to the Chinese embassy[1][9].

items.title: Samsung expects record profit on AI chip demand
items.description:
U.S. stocks retreated from record highs Wednesday as investors paused to reassess risk following a strong start to 2026, while oil prices stabilized after two days of declines and Samsung projected a record-breaking quarterly profit driven by surging demand for AI-related memory chips.

The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average both reached fresh all-time intraday highs during Wednesday's session, with the Dow touching 49,509.92 and the S&P 500 climbing to 6,953.00[1]. However, both indices retreated by the close, ending their three-day winning streaks[2][3]. The Nasdaq Composite edged slightly higher, supported by strength in large-cap technology stocks[2][3].

items.title: Stanford creates octopus-inspired skin that changes color and texture

featured_image.name: Flexible material mimics octopus skin with nanoscale color ...

items.description:
Stanford researchers have developed a flexible synthetic material capable of simultaneously changing both color and texture in seconds, mimicking the camouflage abilities of octopuses and marking what experts describe as one of the most sophisticated artificial camouflage systems ever created.

The breakthrough, published January 7 in Nature, represents the first material that can independently control both visual features on demand[1][2][3]. Lead author Siddharth Doshi, a doctoral student in materials science and engineering at Stanford, explained that the technology replicates essential elements of camouflage found in octopuses, cuttlefish, and squid across various environments[4][5].
